Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Enabling Robust Communication in Cognitive Radio Networks with Multiple Lines of Defense

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Opportunistic spectrum access (OSA) is at the core of the cognitive radio technologies with the focus on improving spectrum utilization efficiency and reliability. Despite the benefits, existing OSA protocols suffer from their deterministic nature and cannot prevent an ill-intended jammer from disrupting legitimate communications. A cognitive jammer can always effectively jam the idle channels by exploiting public-available channel statistics and causes serious spectrum underutilization. This project addresses the challenge of establishing robust anti-jamming communication in cognitive radio networks (CRNs) through a multiple-line of defense approach. The research considers a variety of network environments and integrates defense technologies from different dimensions, including adaptive uncoordinated frequency hopping (AUFH), power control, and signal processing. The defense approach enables both reactive and proactive protections, from evading jammers to competing against jammers, and to expelling jamming signals, and thus ensures robust user communications in CRNs.

The research in this project has a potential to significantly advance the state-of-the-art and develop innovative and sophisticated defense strategies using the proposed multiple lines of defense approach. The proposed solutions will contribute towards eventually building robust and dependable CRNs that are critical to the future communication systems. The project will also contribute directly to the curriculum development, teaching, student supervising and future security engineer training. Major results of this project will be disseminated through presentations, publications, as well as online materials in the forms of tutorials and software packages.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of the project focus on solving several fundamental problems in cognitive radio networks including fair and truthful frequency location, secure acoustic-based communication and secure location-based social networks. We denote our goals as three research modules.

 

Our first research module is the spectrum auction with dynamic spectrum supply. Spectrum/frequency allocation is critical to the successful deployment of cognitive radio networks. We investigate truthful online frequency allocation and fair pricing with dynamic spectrum supply. We further propose to investigate the anti-jamming multi-radio multi-channel access problem in cognitive radio networks (CRNs). We propose to analytically show the convergence of the channel selection algorithms of the sender and the receiver and derive the performance bound. Moreover, the security and robustness of spectrum/channel allocation are critical to the successful deployment of cognitive radio networks. Thus, in this performance period, we propose to investigate the problem of allocating idle channels to spectrum users with homogeneous demands. We propose to design truthful spectrum auctions enabling collusion-resistance and fair payments for homogeneous channels simultaneously under dynamic spectrum supply. In addition, we continue to investigate the problem of secure and robust spectrum auctions in CRNs. Based on our results and findings in collusion-resistant spectrum auction design, we plan to design secure and efficient spectrum auction schemes while enabling spectrum user collusion resistance and/or spectrum user privacy assurance.

 

Our second research module is the secure communication over the wireless channel. In this performance period, we study some related and important networking problems in mobile wireless networks. Specifically, we explore dependable and secure acoustics-based short-range communication. Moreover, theoretically, secure and private communications in cognitive radio networks(CRNs) can be realized when the channel between the legitimate sender and the receiver has an advantage over the eavesdroppers' channel, i.e., the wiretap channel. In this performance period, we propose to design and implement a practical opportunistic secret communication system over the wireless wiretap channel and show the physical limitations and the feasibility of building practical wiretap channels through real-world experiments on the Universal Software Radio Peripheral(USRP) based testbed, which has been widely used to run and evaluate protocol designs for CRNs.

 

Our third research module is the secure location-based social networks (LBSN). In this performance period, we study some related and important networking problems and provide a thorough security analysis and enhancement on mobile social networks. Specifically, we develop an automated user location tracking system, and we further explore enhanced techniques to mitigate security attacks. We further investigate the physical-layer identification in wireless networks. The wireless physical-layer identification (WPLI) techniques utilize the unique features of the physical wave-forms of wireless signals to identify and classify authorized devices, e.g., legitimate spectrum users in CRNs. In this performance period, we propose to evaluate the reliability and the differentiability of the WPLI techniques under the constraints of the state-of-the-art wireless devices (e.g., cognitive radios) and real operating environments.
